sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the creation of a new office macro files on the systems

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects an office document with an embedded VBA project. While this is fairly common it is sometimes used for malicious intent.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered trojan. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

attributes.magic: Composite Document File V2 Document, Little Endian, Os: Windows, Version 10.0, Code page: 1252, Author: windowsmb, Template: Normal.dotm, Last Saved By: windowsmb, Revision Number: 7, Name of Creating Application: Microsoft Office Word, Total Editing Time: 08:00, Create Time/Date: Tue Jul 23 07:51:00 2019, Last Saved Time/Date: Tue Jul 23 08:10:00 2019, Number of Pages: 1, Number of Words: 0, Number of Characters: 0, Security: 0

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis: The macro defines an AutoOpen subroutine which executes upon opening the document. This subroutine uses the Shell command to run "mshta.exe" with a URL as an argument. The URL points to "https://evangelia.edu/image/bin/Rjboi0.hta".  This effectively downloads and executes an HTA (HTML Application) file from the specified URL using the Microsoft HTML Application host program (mshta.exe).

The provided macros exhibit clear signs of malicious intent. The macro defined in the `NewMacros.bas` file contains an `autoopen()` subroutine, which is a common entry point for executing code automatically when the document is opened. Within this subroutine, there is a call to the `Shell` function that executes `mshta.exe`, a legitimate Windows application used to run HTML applications (HTA files). 

The URL specified (`https://evangelia.edu/image/bin/Rjboi0.hta`) indicates that the macro attempts to download and execute a potentially harmful HTA file from an external source. This behavior is particularly concerning as it suggests that the macro is designed to fetch and run code without user consent, which is a hallmark of malware.

Additionally, the use of `mshta.exe` can be indicative of obfuscation techniques, as attackers often leverage this method to bypass security measures or to disguise their actions under the guise of legitimate processes. There are no benign functions or comments present that would suggest a legitimate purpose for this macro; instead, it directly facilitates the execution of external code.

Overall, the combination of automatic execution, external downloads, and the use of a potentially misleading method to run the code strongly points to malicious intent.
